Comic relief

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
Jump to navigation Jump to search
Inclusion of a humorous character, scene, or witty dialogue in an otherwise serious work
This article is about the term "comic relief". For the UK charity, see Comic Relief. For other uses, see Comic Relief (disambiguation).

Comic relief is the inclusion of a humorous character, scene, or witty dialogue in an otherwise serious work, often to relieve tension.

Contents

  • 1 Definition
  • 2 Application
  • 3 History
  • 4 Function
  • 5 Examples
  • 6 References

Definition[edit]

Comic relief usually means a releasing of emotional or other tension resulting from a comic episode interposed in the midst of serious or tragic elements in a drama. Comic relief is often seen but is not limited to, taking the form of a bumbling, wisecracking sidekick of the hero or villain in a work of fiction. A sidekick used for comic relief will usually comment on the absurdity of the hero's situation and make comments that would be inappropriate for a character who is to be taken seriously. Other characters may use comic relief as a means to irritate others or keep themselves confident.

Application[edit]

Sometimes comic relief characters will appear in fiction that is comic. This generally occurs when the work enters a dramatic moment, but the character continues to be comical regardless. External comic reliefs and internal comic reliefs can be separated based on the engagement within the story and the effect on the audience. An internal comic relief[1] is a character or moment where the story is written in the story itself. Others are involved and can laugh along with the humor. While external comic relief[2] moments occur whenever the audience is supposed to laugh but the characters do not.

History[edit]

Greek tragedy did not allow any comic relief within the drama,[3] but had a tradition of concluding a series of several tragic performances with a humorous satyr play. Even the Elizabethan critic Philip Sidney following Horace’s Ars Poetica pleaded for the exclusion of comic elements from a tragic drama. But in the Renaissance England Christopher Marlowe among the University Wits introduced comic relief through the presentation of crude scenes in Doctor Faustus following the native tradition of Interlude which was usually introduced between two tragic plays. In fact, in the classical tradition the mingling of the tragic and the comic was not allowed.

Function[edit]

Comic relief moments serve the purpose[4] to allow the audience to break from the dark and heavy content. It can be a breath of fresh air and advance the plot, though most people view it as a distraction.

Comic relief can be used in a variety of ways. One notable way to utilize comic relief is in education to create a productive learning environment. As Goebel (2009) points out, "Humor can diminish the anxiety and reduce the threatening nature of the material by changing the tone of the instructional process. By reducing anxiety, humor improves student receptiveness to alarming or difficult material, and ultimately has a positive effect on test performance" (p. 1). Reducing stress and anxiety can make learning easier and create an environment that is fun and enjoyable. While studies on the relationship between humor and learning are mixed, there is general agreement that when used in ways directly related to material and objectives being covered, there is improvement in attention, learning, and retention (Goebel, 2009, p. 2). Comic relief can transform a classroom from a stressful experience to a productive, entertaining environment that is enjoyable and one that students look forward to.

Comic relief can also be utilized to teach English as a second language and generate a better understanding. A study conducted also explains how incorporating comic books or comic relief for English learners taking science classes strengthens the students understanding of concepts, practices, and theories (Ardasheva, 2015, p. 2). The illustrations or associations with comical expressions aides in comprehension of the materials and the strategies regarding incorporating comics or comic relief into teaching described in this article would be beneficial for any students—ELL or non-ELL—who need to improve science attitudes and learn the complex language of science (Ardasheva, 2015, p. 8). Incorporating comic relief can be a visual or audio enhancement that can improve student comprehension and process knowledge more efficiently.

As with most things in life, comic relief can also be a double-edge sword with its draw backs. The dark side of comic relief is that it can be employed to create a narrative and control public opinion. Zipj (2022) discussed the use of comedians to do this because people are so malleable and cited ‘Why are many people stupid? Because it’s safe to be with many’, the frequently used quote of comedian De Jonge (p. 3). This is a subtle reference to what is commonly referred to as group thinking. Often this community ideology can be manipulated, especially for political purposes. There needs to be a rethinking of the politics of comedy, breaking away from the deep-seated suspicion of political community-building in the theatre and leaving the ominous idea that ‘those who laugh as a body today will march as a body tomorrow’ (Zipj, 2022 p. 6). This is a reminder of how powerful manipulating the public can be. In short, perhaps it is better to leave comedy to the comedians and politics to the politicians.

This dark side of comic relief has been seen in late night comedy as well. Rob Schneider, who worked on SNL for 4 years in the early 1990’s, said he was glad he left a long time ago because he believes there was a change from comedy relief to indoctrination in late night shows (Del Rosario, 2022, p. 1). Schneider went on to say that “You can take the comedic indoctrination process happening with each of the late-night hosts and you could exchange them with each other. That’s how you know that’s not interesting anymore because...it’s not an independent voice anymore. It’s all just indoctrination by comedic imposition” (Del Rosario, 2022, p. 2). It has long been a debate as to whether entertainment via movies, songs, and comedy relief has been used to shape public opinion. This is just one comedian’s personal experiences that he shared. This does cause one to pause and ponder the possibilities and potential ramifications of abusing comic relief this way.

[5]

Examples[edit]

William Shakespeare deviated from the classical tradition and used comic relief in Hamlet, Macbeth, Othello, The Merchant of Venice and Romeo and Juliet. The grave-digger scene in Hamlet, the gulling of Roderigo, and the mockery of the fool in King Lear provide immense comic relief.[6]

Take the Porter scene in Macbeth,:[7]

"Here's a knocking indeed! If a man were porter of hell-gate, he should have old turning the key…Who's there, i' the name of Beelzebub? Here's a farmer, that hanged himself on the expectation of plenty: come in time; have napkins enow about you; here you'll sweat for't…Faith, here's an English tailor come hither, for stealing out of a French hose: come in, tailor; here you may roast your goose."[8]

In this scene, the Porter serves as the comedic relief. In the scene before, King Duncan is murdered by the Macbeth duo. After the scene, his body is discovered and the castle is thrown into hysteria. His chaotic scene in between serves as a comic relief moment to distract the audience from the gruesome content.
